newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Russian doctor seeks funds for brain disease cure.
newsitem.headline: Russian doctor seeks funds for brain disease cure.

text.p: A Russian doctor called for funds and facilities on Thursday to test a new method to deliver drugs directly into the brain, by-passing the bloodstream, claiming this would help cure mad cow and other brain diseases.

A British government admission last year that people eating infected beef could catch Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease, a human equivalent of mad cow disease which has killed over 165,000 British cattle, triggered widespread panic.
The invention, which means that drugs no longer have to be injected or swallowed, could be used to treat multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's syndrome, Alzheimer's disease, epilepsy and other illnesses.
"Thousands of people are dying daily from diseases, people who can be cured," Amsterdam-based neurologist Eduard Lerner, 68, told a news conference.
Lerner, who moved to the Netherlands in 1990, formerly headed a cardiology research team in Moscow.

The invention consists of a battery-powered machine wired to an electrode placed on the patient's head. A current pushes the drug into the brain through nervous tissue, Lerner said, adding that the precise location of the spot was secret.
"Many hundreds of (Russian) patients have been treated and I have never seen any complications," he claimed.
Lerner said he had conducted experiments at Nijmegen University in the Netherlands but four months ago it stopped the programme, saying it didn't have the money or laboratories to continue.
University officials were not immediately available for comment.
Lerner said leading pharmaceutical companies had shown great interest. "Everyone is interested but they want to keep full (commercial) control," he said.
